feed.title: The Register
feed.subtitle: Biting the hand that feeds IT — sci/tech news and views for the world

entry.title: HP chairman Lane yields to 'here's you hat, what's your hurry?'
entry.summary:
Two other beleaguered directors also exit, stage left

Succumbing to pressure to shake up the board of directors of HP, chairman Ray Lane is stepping down from running the board. However, he said in a statement, he will remain on the HP board – even if he doesn't run it.…

entry.title: Patch time for PostgreSQL
entry.summary:
Crashable and hackable

The maintainers of the PostgreSQL database have released an urgent patch to cope with a vulnerability that allows remote users to crash servers, while authenticated users can execute arbitrary code.…

entry.title: Visual Studio 2012 Update 2 delivers modest improvements
entry.summary:
One bright spot: the IDE now comes in blue, too

In keeping with its vow to ship updates for its flagship software development tools in "a regular cadence," Microsoft has delivered Visual Studio 2012 Update 2 just a little over four months after it shipped the last one.…

entry.title: Google inflates infrastructure cloud
entry.summary:
Makes it easier to get on, trims prices

Google has taken another step toward opening up its Amazon-competitor Google Compute Engine to the general public.…

entry.title: Oracle gussies up Xsigo switching as Virtual Networking and SDN
entry.summary:
Lashes new Sparc T5 and M5 servers to each other and storage

Oracle is ratcheting up the virtual networking wars with the relaunch of its Xsigo line of I/O director switches.…

entry.title: Gates and Allen reshoot historic 1981 Microsoft photo
entry.summary:
Holding back the years

One of the most iconic photos from the history of Microsoft, featuring a lanky young Bill Gates perched next to his coding mentor (the way he tells it) Paul Allen, has been recreated at Seattle's Living Computing Museum.…

entry.title: Steve Jobs' 'spaceship' threatened by massive cost overruns
entry.summary:
Will shareholders balk at $5bn price tag? Stay tuned...

Comment  It appears that the late Steve Jobs' dream of new "spaceship" Apple headquarters is going to cost far more than the $3bn originally planned – that is, if it gets built at all.…

entry.title: WebKit devs on Blink fork: 'Two can play that game'
entry.summary:
Purge of Chrome-related code planned

Now that Google has announced that it will migrate its Chrome browser from the WebKit rendering engine to a homegrown fork called Blink, WebKit developers have already begun discussing how to remove Chrome-specific code from the project.…

entry.title: Facebook skins Android with Facebook Home
entry.summary:
Zuck on this, unless you care about privacy

Facebook has taken over Android with an application named Facebook Home that slaps a social façade on top of Google's operating system.…

entry.title: Leaked memo: Apple's iMessage crypto has DEA outfoxed
entry.summary:
Feds want more back-door access

Analysis  An investigation by the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) in February was temporarily thwarted when the surveillance targets began using Apple's encrypted iMessage system, according to a document leaked to Cnet.…

entry.title: Has Europe finally passed Peak Disk?
entry.summary:
Tablets, cloud, THAT Thai flood mentioned as platters spin down

Disk drive sales in the EMEA region have showed falls in both units and capacity according to research from Futuresource Consulting.…

entry.title: Shark-tooth war cutlery reveals tale of fishy extinction in Pacific
entry.summary:
A story with real bite emerges from chomp-cutlasses

They are the sort of weapons that could be worth hundreds to your average tooth fairy.…

entry.title: OpenStack 'Grizzly' control freak puffs up clouds of vastness
entry.summary:
Parity support across hypervisors, broader networking, other goodies

The OpenStack community is keeping faithful to its six-month spring-fall cadence for software releases: today, the world receives an OpenStack update codenamed Grizzly.…

entry.title: If only enterprise IT worked like my iPad ... or at least my car
entry.summary:
Architects and biz chiefs still not talking

Opinion  Do you remember when computers were hard to use?…

entry.title: Sci/Tech quango promises an end to 'events with no women'
entry.summary:
Except when its own management get together

Sci-tech quango Nesta has announced a ban on all-male panels at its events in a bid to challenge the blokeyness endemic in the fields it covers.…

entry.title: Anonymous joins forces with arch-enemy The Jester against Norks
entry.summary:
If you're where that Venn diagram overlaps ... question yourself

Hacktivist collective Anonymous and - unusually - some of its enemies have all turned their ire against government websites, propaganda outlets and social media profiles linked to the North Korean regime.…

entry.title: Guide man Frommer buys his name back from Google, plans eBooks
entry.summary:
Presumably nobody will seek the content in Google+

Google has handed the rights to the Frommer brand of travel guides back to Arthur Frommer, after the Chocolate Factory snapped it up from publisher Wiley just last year.…

entry.title: Got a Sophos Web Protection box? Make sure it's up to date
entry.summary:
Scary vuln left keys to your kingdom up for grabs

Sophos has plugged security holes in its Web Protection Appliance that could place its customers' internet connections in the hands of eavesdroppers.…

entry.title: Mars to go offline for a month as vast nuclear furnace gets in the way
entry.summary:
Ha ha, chuckle Martians, time to play!

Spacecraft exploring and orbiting Mars will be left alone for the next month as the red planet slips behind our nearest star for a bit of a spring break.…

entry.title: Google goes on the Blink in WebKit fork FURORE
entry.summary:
Diversity be damned: The view from Mountain View

Comment  When Opera Software killed its web browser's rendering engine Presto, and announced it will instead use WebKit, the company did so with the best intentions.…

entry.title: Bitcoin briefly soars to record $147 high, driven by Cyprus bank flap
entry.summary:
Attraction of non-gov currency draws punters

Virtual currency Bitcoin soared to a record high of nearly $147 yesterday as Euro-spurred interest continued to boost its exchange rate.…

entry.title: Advanced Persistent Threats get more advanced, persistent and threatening
entry.summary:
What it says on the security biz tin

Organisations are getting hit with a malicious email attachment or web link designed to evade legacy defences up to once every three minutes, according to a report by security biz FireEye.…

entry.title: Ancient website from 1999: By Mark Zuckerberg aged 15¾
entry.summary:
I will put you on The Web and link you ... bitch

A website that might just have been created by a 15-year-old Mark Zuckerberg way back in 1999 has been uncovered by Hacker News.…

entry.title: Building the actual real internet simply doesn't pay
entry.summary:
Those fat pipes and extra Gs don't come cheap

Analysis  It isn’t unicorns that keep the internets running, but eye-watering amounts of capital investment by infrastructure operators. However a substantial chunk of that investment never pays for itself and most of it barely repays the cost of the capital, reckons consultancy PwC.…

entry.title: Provider of FIFA goal line tech chosen, tracks ball in space and time
entry.summary:
Strangely a German firm, not one in Qatar

Football governing body FIFA has selected goal-line technology from German firm GoalControl as its preferred option in trials ahead of the 2014 World Cup.…

entry.title: LOHAN must suck juice while mounted on rigid rod - but HOW?
entry.summary:
Possible hot coupling for Vulture 2

Over the past couple of weeks, the Low Orbit Helium Assisted Navigator (LOHAN) team has been chewing the fat with readers over just how to hook up the Vulture 2 spaceplane's rocket motor heater.…

entry.title: Disney shutters Star Wars game unit with 200 layoffs
entry.summary:
Incredibly appreciative and proud of the talented jobless

Just a few months after snapping up George Lucas' Star Wars empire, Disney is shutting down its game unit LucasArts and laying off around 200 employees.…

entry.title: Cisco gobbles UK mobe mast maker - you know where this is going
entry.summary:
Tiny cells in your Wi-Fi router - checkmate, Huawei

Swindon-based Ubiquisys will soon be part of Cisco in a $310m (£205m) buyout. The networking colossus has, in effect, snapped up more than 50 customers wanting small cellular base stations and the technology they want.…

entry.title: IBM: We have placed the Big Data moon on this stick
entry.summary:
Big BLU claims from Big Blue

IBM Research has come up with a new package it calls BLU Acceleration, intended to speed up (big) data analysis and reporting of data held in DB2 and Informix databases, amongst others.…

entry.title: Wikileaker Manning peace gong petition backed by thousands
entry.summary:
Something to treasure while in military confinement

Nearly 40,000 people have signed a petition calling for Wikileaker Bradley Manning to be awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.…

entry.title: Hostile Xyratex investors claim CEO's scalp in aggressive haircut
entry.summary:
Show us the money, says Baker Street

Activist investors have forced out Xyratex CEO Steve Barber in their hunt for a bigger and faster return on their investment.…

entry.title: Review: Intel Next Unit of Computing barebones desktop PC
entry.summary:
Is Chipzilla's nano machine too polished to rival the rough'n'ready Raspberry Pi?

Intel must really like the sound of its own ‘voice’. How else can you explain the fact that sliding open the box containing the chip giant’s latest desktop package plays the ding-da-ding-ding-ding jingle as soon as you open it. Amaze your friends! Irritate your colleagues! Keep opening and closing the box to replay the ditty over and over and over...…

entry.title: Google offers Adwords deals - but you can't trust their numbers
entry.summary:
A load of balls from Mountain View's maths wizards

Google's Adwords platform has always been something of a mystery, to put it mildly - the only certainty about it is that it makes a lot of money for Google - but nobody has caught it out using numbers which are definitely, verifiably untrue.…

entry.title: Bank card-slurp nasty 'infects tills, ATMs', corrupt staff fingered
entry.summary:
Internet hitman flogs account-snaffling malware to forgers

Audacious crooks have infected hundreds of shopping tills and cash machines with malware to swipe sensitive debit and credit card data, we're told.…

entry.title: Universal Credit IT system could lead to MORE FRAUD, MPs warn
entry.summary:
Parliament snores slightly in sleep, rolls over

The number of benefit cheats in the UK could rise thanks to yet more IT problems with the government's new Universal Credit system, MPs warn.…

entry.title: Hate being stalked by Facebook? Why not try Google+ stalking
entry.summary:
Offering ad guys that crucial Bieber-Beeber demographic

Google is fattening up its single sign-in feature that was opened up to mobile and web apps in February. This is the feature that allows netizens to use their Google+ usernames and passwords to log into accounts on third-party systems.…

entry.title: ‘Unstoppable WEEE Tsunami’ staunched by PPP plan
entry.summary:
Governments, ITU, want to transform waste electrical and electronic equipment

The International Telecommunications Union (ITU) and several Central American Governments have decided waste electrical and electronic equipment (WEEE) is both a threat to and an opportunity for the region.…

entry.title: NetApp snoozing at the wheel of incumbency juggernaut, says chap
entry.summary:
Wake up and sniff those clouds for pity's sake

Equity analyst firm William Blair thinks NetApp is failing to face up to the realities of being an incumbent storage supplier, and could even exit the hardware business.…

entry.title: Boffins shine new light on dark matter
entry.summary:
Giant magnet in space shows 'existence of new physical phenomena'

The LHC may have found the Higgs Boson, but overarching theories of everything have another hole: the observable universe weighs rather less than it ought if all those equations – and all the galaxies - are to hang together.…

entry.title: RAF graduates first class of new groundbased 'pilots'
entry.summary:
Per ardua ad ... terra

The Royal Air Force is chuffed this week to announce the graduation of its first class of "remotely piloted air system pilots", who have the job of piloting aircraft they are not actually in.…

entry.title: STEC - sorry sTec - opens direct and channel sales with name change
entry.summary:
Sales people who do customer support? Hmm

What the Zeus is going on? STEC has changed to sTec and it's bragging about its new direct and channel sales program.…

entry.title: Swedish judge explains big obstacles to US Assange extradition
entry.summary:
Wikileaker's bizarre bonking behaviour revealed, along with likely legal escapes

A senior judge from Sweden’s supreme court, Justice Stefan Lindskog, has told an Australian audience that Julian Assange’s argument he cannot stand trial in Sweden without being extradited to the USA is not as black and white as the wikileaker would have us believe.…

entry.title: Kiwi boffins bid up Earth-like planet prediction
entry.summary:
A HUNDRED beeellion!

We'll see your lousy 17 billion Earth-like planets, Smithsonian, and raise you 83 billion: that's the message coming out of a New Zealand group that's proposing a new detection technique in the Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society.…

entry.title: General Motors bakes Siri into Oz hatchback
entry.summary:
'Siri, this doesn't look like Mildura'

General Motors' antipodean outpost, Holden, is trying to put a bit of cool into its four-cylinder shopping trolley, the Barina, by integrating Siri into its electronics.…

entry.title: CloudSigma spins-up all-SSD storage cloud
entry.summary:
Flash, a-ah, saviour of the Euro-cloud

Zurich-based infrastructure-as-a-service slinger CloudSigma has moved to all flash storage for the data center infrastructure running its cloud.…

entry.title: Google forks WebKit, promises faster, leaner Chrome engine
entry.summary:
Says 'large-scale architectural changes' coming

Google has announced that its Chrome browser is dropping the popular WebKit browser engine in favor of Blink, a new fork of the code that the Chocolate Factory says will make Chrome faster, more powerful, and more secure.…

entry.title: Is NBN Co about to pay for 80 years of power pole access?
entry.summary:
Historical prices for HFC access suggest NSW Government overcharging massively

According to the NSW State Government, NBN Co is being completely unreasonable in declining to fork over in the order of $400 million for access to electricity poles in that state. In response, NBN Co is, as it warned it would in October 2012, invoking the Telecommunications Act and using the poles without electricity authority permission.…

entry.title: IBM readies PureData Hadoop appliance for the summer
entry.summary:
Bolts Big SQL query onto its BigInsights Hadoop distro

IBM wants to make it easier for companies to consume and use Hadoop, just like everyone else who is chasing that yellow elephant that likes to munch big data.…

entry.title: PaaS Heroku's misleading of customers poisons the cloud
entry.summary:
If you can't trust providers, then why outsource in the first place?

Comment  Platform-as-a-service Heroku spent two years misleading customers because it was so focused on building a new product that it didn't bother to update old documentation – this is unacceptable.…

entry.title: Australia to reveal tech giants' tax tricks
entry.summary:
Opening up the Dutch sandwich to reveal the shameful ingredients

Australia's assistant treasurer David Bradbury has outlined a plan to make the ingredients of the infamous “Double Irish Dutch Sandwich” – a recipe for tax minimisation used by tech giants - known to all, so that the public can understand just what the likes of Apple, Microsoft and Google are up to.…
